The genome of Candidatus Erwinia haradaeae is relatively small, indicating that it has undergone significant genome reduction due to its symbiotic lifestyle. It is believed to play a role in the metabolism and nutrition of its host, potentially providing essential nutrients or contributing to the insect's ability to thrive on its host plant.

However, the precise nature of the relationship between Candidatus Erwinia haradaeae and its host, the brown planthopper, is still under investigation. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological and evolutionary significance of this endosymbiotic bacterial species.
